1.content:
My name is Janelle Lee, and I'm 17.

Let me tell you about my life before I graduated high school. I lived in a two-story contemporary with my parents, Stephen and Anita, and my younger sister, Courtney. My bedroom, like Courtney's, was on the second floor. I got my red hair from Mom, and my brown eyes from Dad. In high school, I was a cheerleader (Go Cats!), and I was dating Brad Butler, captain of the football team.

Now, before you go thinking this sounds too cliche, there are a couple of differences from the typical story. First, I wasn't head cheerleader. That was my friend, Mindy Kier. She wasn't jealous of me, because she already had a girlfriend, Zooey Hirsch. I was her friend, too. That's right, I was the straight best friend.

The second difference from the usual is that I was a vegetarian. I wasn't one of those protest-the-lunch-room-for-serving-meat vegetarians, but I did take pride in refusing to eat or drink anything that came from something with a face. Mom joined me in eating vegetarian, Dad learned how to cook veggie burgers and veggie dogs on the grill, and Courtney left me to it, even sticking up for me when my uncle would mockingly ask if I could hear the cow screaming as he bit into his burger. As for my friends, they were supportive, and Brad didn't even mind my intestinal gas.

So, that was my life before graduation.

After graduation, I can safely say, it sucked.

******************************


After the graduation ceremony, I went out to celebrate my first night of freedom. That's what I called it, anyway, as if I didn't have college to get ready for at the end of summer. But hey, that was months away, and I could still have fun and go to the movies for a good solid month or two. On this night, my curfew was extended to midnight, and I wanted to let loose.

It was at this underground rave that I'd snuck into where I met him. He said his name was Micah, and he was chill with the fact that I wasn't invited. We danced for a while, then he brought me a soda, for which I thanked him.

It didn't occur to me for half an hour that maybe I should have gotten my own drink. By then, of course, I was feeling the effects of whatever he'd slipped into it. As I started reeling, Micah and three of his buddies began half leading, half carrying me somewhere private. I vaguely remember them taking off some of my clothes.

But I vividly remember them biting me. Micah at my throat, one buddy at each arm, and one sinking his teeth into my thigh. My God, I thought, I'm being eaten alive!

As the darkness pulled me down, I remember thinking, Please, God, don't let me die...

******************************


The next thing I remember was water washing over me. It was too little to be a river, but the fact that I was lying on my back meant it couldn't be a shower.

The water stopped, and I heard a woman's voice: "... name is Janelle Lee, 17 years of age. What are you doing here, Janelle?" Her words were addressed to me, but her tone sounded like she was talking to herself. "You should be starting a summer job, or going to a movie with your friends. What happened to put you here?"

"Four guys," I said.

"Holy shit!"

That reaction surprised me, so I opened my eyes and sat up. The woman was about Mom's age, and she was trying to compose herself. That's when I noticed that I was naked.

Only one way to get the answers I needed. "Who are you? Where am I? Why am I naked? What's going on?"

She nodded. "I'm Dr. Joanna Kinski, the county coroner. You are in the morgue. I cut your clothing off your body. And I was about to perform an autopsy on you."
1.title: The Night that Sucked

11.content:
Dr. Kinski gave me some scrubs to wear, then called my folks. After telling them what had happened and where I was, she handed the phone to me. "Daddy?"

"Sweetie, thank God you're alright!" Dad said. "I got a call that the car was impounded, nobody knew where you were. You gave us quite a scare, young lady."

"Me, too, Daddy."

"I think we'll chalk this one up to a lesson learned. We'll discuss it further when we're all home. We'll see you soon. Love you, honey."

"Love you, too, Daddy. Goodbye."

After I hung up the phone, I turned to Dr. Kinski. "I know this may sound strange, but something smells awfully good, and I'm starving."

She pointed to a corner. "I've got some pad Thai. You're welcome to half, if you don't mind vegan food."

I paused just long enough to kiss her on the lips, then went over to the corner and sat down.

I put one forkful into my mouth when I realized that something was wrong. Pad Thai has a lot of flavors; it shouldn't taste like Styrofoam.

I swallowed, and immediately regretted it. I ran to the sink and threw up. "What's wrong with me?"

I felt a gentle squeeze on each shoulder. "I'm a doctor," Dr. Kinski said. "Let's see if we can find out."

After sitting me down, Dr. Kinski put a thermometer in my mouth, wrapped a blood pressure cuff around my left arm, and clamped a sensor on my right index finger. Then she turned on the machine.

When it was done, she looked even more afraid than when I spoke on the slab. "What is it?" I asked.

She turned the machine in my direction.

Temperature: 55°.

Heart rate: 0.

Blood pressure: 0/0.

Blood oxygen level: 0.

"I would expect these readings," she said, "if I had hooked this up to one of the people in the drawers."

My jaw dropped. "How could this happen?"

"If I may ask," she asked, "how long have you had those?"

I looked in a mirror. If my heart rate weren't already zero, it would have stopped. "My God."

I woke up in the morgue. My vital signs said I was dead. And I had fangs.

Put it all together, and it spells vampire.
11.title: Something Is Wrong

111.content:
"Vampire?"

I nodded. "It's the only thing that fits everything."

Dr. Kinski shook her head. "It still seems so hard to believe."

"Okay," I replied, "you think there's some other explanation for me being a walking, talking corpse with fangs. But I've narrowed down the appetizing smell I mentioned earlier." I pointed to a mini-fridge. "You haven't opened it since I woke up, but I'm betting there's blood in there."

She looked defeated. "I guess there's just one thing left to verify, then."

She opened the fridge and took out a bag of blood, then tossed it to me.

I sipped some of it. It was coppery and sweet. It was the first thing I'd had in my mouth since I was 12 that wasn't plant-based.

And it was the best thing I'd ever tasted.

I opened a hole at the other end and shotgunned the blood into my mouth.

And that's when my family walked in.

Dad looked like he was going to be sick. Mom fainted.

And Courtney, who read every YA vampire romance novel she could get her hands on, said just one word: "Awesome!"
111.title: My First Taste of Blood

1111.content:
Once Mom regained consciousness, Dr. Kinski and I told everyone what we knew. Dr. Kinski gave me a cooler filled with blood bags, and we started heading outside.

The trouble was, it was late afternoon, which meant the sun was still out.

I slowly extended one hand into the light, then yanked it back with a hiss. "We've got a problem."

******************************


After a quick visit with Dr. Kinski, we headed back out. This time, I was also wearing oversized sunglasses and an even more oversized hoodie. I pulled the hood almost closed, then pulled the sleeves over my hands. With my skin almost completely covered, I was able to go outside, guided by Mom and Courtney.

Back home, Mom and Dad sent me to the rec room in the basement until the sun went down. I had two more bags while I waited.

Once the sun was down, we moved my stuff from the second floor to the guest bedroom in the basement. I did most of the heavy lifting. Dad put my blood bags into the fridge in the rec room, then said, "Tomorrow, we'll pick you up a mini-fridge, so you can keep them out of sight. As for the window, we can just put a blanket over it."
1111.title: The Trouble with Sunlight

11111.content:
Once I was settled in in the basement, Mom and Dad announced that it was time for them to go to bed, and they all went upstairs. Courtney, however, came back down. "I brought you something for your new room." She handed me a framed poem she had written:

The vampire looked down on the city below.
He was once like them, fearful, but did not know.
Most of his kind do not kill those whom they choose to feed.
They give a cure to what ails them for the blood they need.
He was near dead when the vampire gave him the dark gift.
Revealing they are dark guardians gave him a lift.
Vampires stand guard when the skies turn black.
When things go bump in the night, they are the ones who bump back.


"Have you lost your mind?" I asked her. "This wasn't a gift. The only thing worse than what those... things did to me, is knowing that I will do the same thing to you, if I'm not extremely careful all the time."

Courtney shook her head. "You wouldn't do that. Not to me. Not to anyone."

"How do you know that?"

"You told me yourself. When you realized that you'd become a vampire, you let Dr. Kinski give you blood bags. If you wouldn't attack a total stranger for the blood you need, you won't attack anyone else." She stepped closer to me. "Those boys were wrong to attack you. But you aren't condemned to becoming like them. You're still my big sister, Janelle."

I pulled her in and hugged her as tightly as I dared. "I'm so scared, Court. I don't want to be afraid."

She looked up at me and smiled. "You've already got that Dr. Seuss quote."

I smiled, knowing exactly the one she meant:

For I've bought a big bat
I'm all ready, you see
Now my troubles are going
To have troubles with me!
11111.title: My First Night of Undeath

111111.content:
It was weird, being a creature of the night in a house where everyone else was asleep. There was a part of me that wanted to go out, to explore the city after all the normal people were in bed. But I stayed home. After all, I had gone out last night, and got turned into a vampire. Mom and Dad had tabled the discussion of whether I should be disciplined for scaring them once. If I did it again, I might come home to find the blanket taken down, letting sunlight in while I needed rest.

Luckily for me, I found some movies to watch late at night. And they weren't horror movies, so I didn't have to look at make-believe vampires while I was dealing with being a real one.

As I watched, I heard a noise that didn't belong. Someone had entered the house, while Mom and Dad slept, if fitfully, and Courtney snored.

I stood up. Wrong house, wrong night, I thought.

I crept up the stairs, marveling at how quiet I was being. Even the creaky stair wasn't giving me away.

I opened the basement door a crack and peeked out. There he was, getting the lay of the land. No doubt congratulating himself on not arousing the homeowners.

As he stepped toward the big screen TV, I made my move. I ran right up into his face and hissed, fangs bared.

I can't say which felt more rewarding: his high-pitched scream, him running for his life, or the unmistakable odor that signaled that he had voided his bladder and bowels simultaneously.

A light went on down the hall. "Who's there?" Dad called out.

"Just me, now, Daddy," I called back. "We had a burglar, but I scared him off."

After closing up the house again, I went back down to the basement. I smiled, thinking about Courtney's poem: The burglar had gone bump in the night, and I had certainly bumped back.
111111.title: Later That Night

1111111.content:
About half an hour before the sun came up, I began to feel tired, so I got ready for bed. I was about to crawl under the sheet when Dad knocked on my door. "Got a minute?"

"Not a lot of them, but yeah," I replied.

He opened the door. "We're going to have a security system installed this afternoon, if you can be up by then."

I shrugged. "Hard to say. I'm not even sure if I can sleep in a bed."

"Well, try, pumpkin. You shouldn't be obligated to protect us. And what if a burglar came while we were out and you were... ?"

I nodded. "Point taken. If I can wake myself up, I will do so."

"Good girl. So you know, you're not grounded or anything. Your death is punishment enough, for all of us."

I nodded. "I'll just need to let you guys know when I'm headed out, and punch in the codes when I come and go."

"Can you... change at all? You know, like... " He flapped his hands at his shoulders, like bat wings.

"I haven't done it yet. I don't even know if I can. It would be so much easier if one of those guys stuck around to give me pointers on this. Now, if you'll excuse me, Daddy, I'm dragging."

"Sleep well, Janelle." He closed the door.

I got into bed, wondering if my bed would be enough, or would I need a coff -

And that was as far as I got before I was out like a light.
1111111.title: Bedtime for Me

11111111.content:
I awakened shortly after noon. Hearing no conversation about letting anyone into my room, I guessed that I was up in time. Trying a shower, I was relieved to find that I could. My old body wash didn't smell or feel right anymore, but at least the water could get me clean. I got dressed and had a bag of blood, and I was ready to deal with people. I signaled that fact by knocking on the basement door.

Courtney came down. "Just so you know," she said, "Dad told the security company that you're photosensitive, which is why you're sitting down here and staying out of the sunlight." She hung out with me while we waited.

About an hour later, workers from the security company came down. "They told us your daughter was photosensitive," one of them said. "With your permission, I'd like to show you a laminate that's worked quite well for other people dealing with photosensitivity. If it doesn't work, you won't have to pay a penny for our work here today."

Dad looked to me. In order to play the brave, suffering daughter, I nodded, and they laminated one window in the rec room.

To my surprise, when I put my hand in the sunbeam that went through the laminate, my hand didn't hurt at all, and Dad agreed to let them laminate the whole window and the window in my bedroom. "This laminate also prevents the glass from shattering as easily," the man said.

It felt good to be able to look out the window again. I almost felt like a person. They offered to laminate the first floor windows, but Dad said that would have to wait a while, given the cost.

As the installation team left, Mindy and Zooey came down. "There you are," Mindy said. "Your folks told us you went missing, but they didn't say they found you again. And why are you down here? What's wrong with your old bedroom?"

I sighed. "It takes some explaining... "
11111111.title: The Next Afternoon

111111111.content:
"After graduation," I said, "I wanted to celebrate, to cut loose with a night on the town. At one point, I found this underground rave. It was supposed to be by invitation only, but the music was good, so I snuck in. That's where it happened."

"Where what happened?" Zooey asked.

"Where I died."

"Excuse me," Mom said, and went upstairs.

"You died?" Mindy asked. "Come on, Janelle, isn't that a bit dramatic for you? I mean, you're right here, how dead can you be?"

I offered Mindy my hand. She took it, then dropped it. "How'd you get your hand so cold?"

"My body no longer generates heat," I said. "I no longer have a pulse. I inhale only when I'm about to speak. And then there's these." I showed them my fangs.

"Janelle," Zooey asked, "are you... are you saying that you... that you're... ?"

"A vampire. At the rave, I was gang-bitten by four vampires, and one of them vamped me up. That's why I'm down here now. Upstairs is too sunny for me, the sunlight causes me physical pain. Look in the fridge, you'll find the only stuff that will go down my throat."

Mindy looked. "Blood... " she whispered. Turning to me, she asked, "Are you okay, Janelle?"

"I'm not sure how to answer that. Will I get better? You don't get better from being undead. Am I happy? Not by a long shot. I've gone from 'None of my food has a face' to 'All my food has faces, and names, and jobs they hate.'"

They were quiet for a long time. Then they put their arms around me, Mindy first, then Zooey.

"You can't go out during the day," Mindy said, "so we'll come back after the sun goes down, and take you out to a movie. How's that sound?"

I smiled. "I think I'd like that. What's the movie?"

"It's a surprise."
111111111.title: Telling My Friends

1111111111.content:
"You've got our number," Dad asked, "in case you run into trouble?"

"Yes, Daddy," I replied. Actually, I would be able to handle most of the trouble I might run into, and he knew it. But I guess he still wanted to feel like he was protecting me.

"You know, you don't have to keep calling me Daddy."

"You used to think it was cute." I turned to Mom. "How long did you call Grandpa Daddy?"

"All the way through college," she replied. Then, sensing she'd touched something, she said, "You go on calling your father Daddy for as long as you're comfortable, Janelle."

Before anyone could say anything else, Mindy and Zooey arrived. "All set?"

I walked toward them. "Let's do it."

******************************


The movie turned out to be My Life in Miniature, about some kids our age who find themselves shrinking to doll size. It was an entertaining movie, and it almost took my mind off the conversation I'd had with my parents right before I left.

Dad had said that I didn't need to call him Daddy anymore, and Mom had said she had called her father Daddy until she graduated college. The thing was, of course, I wouldn't be going to college anymore. College was for people who could walk in the sunshine. College was for people who could eat in the cafeteria. College was for people who were still alive.

And then, of course, my not going to college was a reminder that I hadn't seen Brad since grad night, and I hadn't talked to him on the phone, either. Sooner or later, I would have to sit down and talk with him, like I did with Mindy and Zooey, and tell him how things had changed. How I had changed.

The girls dropped me off in front of the house, and we promised we'd do this again soon. I walked into the house, prepared to resume our discussion.

I didn't get the chance, however. Mom wasn't in the living room, and three strangers dressed in black were. Two men and a woman. The woman had hair as red as mine. "Janelle Lee?" she asked.

"Yes. Where's Mom?"

"She went off to her bedroom," the woman said, her voice with just a touch of an Irish accent. "She didn't want to be party to this discussion."

I looked at Dad, and he nodded. The woman was telling the truth. "You have me at a disadvantage, Miss... ?"

"My name is Finola," she said. "These are my associates, Llewellyn and Blackwell." Then, showing her fangs, she said, "It's part of my job to deal with those like you."
1111111111.title: At the Movies

11111111111.content:
"How did you know?" I asked. "And I thought we had to be invited to walk into someone else's house."

"We do," one of the men replied. "And you put a mat out front that said we were welcome."

"As for how we knew," Finola said, "I have a thrall in the medical examiner's office, who told me that a certain young lady woke up on the slab and went home with her family. That is, after she needed help dealing with the afternoon sun. I sent another thrall to verify, and you confirmed it. All I needed to do after that was arrange for our security company to offer protective laminate."

So that wasn't a burglar, I thought. He came to see if I was really a vampire. And I couldn't have done a better job of proving I was.

"Now that I've answered your questions," Finola said, "it's time for you to answer mine. To begin with, tell me about how you were born to darkness."

"'Born to darkness,'" I said. "More accurate than 'dark gift.' There isn't much to tell. I snuck into this underground rave, met a guy named Micah, and he and three of his buddies bit me. Next thing I know, I'm in the morgue. That's all I've got for you."

"More than you know," Finola said. "Thanks to you, we now know that the ringleader is named Micah, and they're using an underground rave as their cover. We're one step closer to removing their threat to the Masquerade."

"The Masquerade?"

"The idea that there's no such thing as vampires," Courtney explained.

"You've been of great help, Janelle." Finola handed me a card. "Call us if you need any help."

"As a matter of fact, I do. I know cheerleading, not bloodsucking. If I'm going to make it long enough to need your help, I need to know what being a vampire means."

Finola nodded. "True. Usually, your sire would teach you about this. But these rogues aren't good at responsibility." She extended a hand. "Your first lesson begins tonight, colleen. Come along."
11111111111.title: The Cleaning Crew

111111111111.content:
After bidding my goodbyes to Dad and Courtney - and calling out goodbye to Mom - I followed Finola and her colleagues to a black SUV, and got in. "Devil a one of us didn't have a ton of questions for our sires, Janelle ," Finola said. "Ask us anything."

"Can we change into bats, like in the movies?"

"You'll need a few centuries behind you before you try that one," Llewellyn replied. "And, even then, it'll take a lot out of you. Elder vampires only do that for fast getaways and dramatic entrances."

"I'd always heard that vampires had no reflection, but I've got one. What's the truth?"

"Centuries ago," Blackwell explained, "mirrors were made with silver backing. We can't stand silver, but mortals thought we were reacting to the mirrors. Now, they make mirrors with aluminum instead."

"How about crosses, holy water, all that stuff?"

"Stuff is what that is," Llewellyn said. "Stuff and nonsense. Before the Masquerade, the Church went after us like we were a threat. Of course we were afraid when someone started flinging those things around, who wouldn't be? But they've got no power of their own."

"Can... No, forget it, you'll think it's silly."

"Oi," Blackwell said, "Finola said you were to ask us anything. Ask it, girl."

"Can we have children?"

"Now, you've only been one of us since yesterday," Finola said, "and your da said you'd only just finished high school. What's got you thinking about babies?"

"Well, my cousin had one a couple of months ago. At the time, I thought, Sucks to be her. But now, I kind of wonder."

Finola sighed. "I won't lie to you, colleen: Every now and then, a male vampire will get a mortal woman pregnant. But no female vampire has had a period, never mind gotten pregnant. I'm sorry."
111111111111.title: My First Lesson

1111111111111.content:
After I was sure I had asked every question I could think of, Finola brought me home. "I'll come back next week, colleen," she said, "we'll chat again."

"Already looking forward to it," I said.

I expected that the door would be locked, and that I would have to punch in the alarm code. However, when I tried my key, the door opened, and Mom stood there. "How was your night?" she asked, as if I was just getting back from being out with Mindy and Zooey.

"I learned a lot," I replied. "Turns out I can't have children."

"I didn't know you were thinking about it."

"I wasn't. Still, it hurts knowing that the decision has been made for you. Mom, I... I know you're not comfortable talking about me, but I hope you can understand what I'm going through."

Mom responded by hugging me hard enough to squeeze the life out of me, if I'd still been alive. "Janelle, I know what happened to you. I know everything is different for you, and I know why. I haven't been using the words, not because I'm ashamed of you, but because... Part of me feels like, if I start calling you those things, it's like I'm abandoning you. Worse, it's like I'm forsaking you." She kissed me. "You are my daughter, Janelle, first, last, and always. The rest is details. I'm sorry I made you doubt that, even a little."

"It's okay, Mom," I told her. "I use the words myself. You're not going to hurt me by saying them. If anything, you'll be telling me you accept me for what I am. Go on, give it a try."

Still embracing me, Mom took a deep breath, to steady her nerves. Then, looking me square in the face, she said, "You... you died."

I nodded. "I did."

"You're... undead."

"I am."

"You're a... a vampire."

"I am. How do you feel?"

She patted me on the back. "Like a wall just came down, and I can see the view. Oh, by the way." She handed me a brown paper bag. "Finola said these would be better for your skin than commercial soaps and shampoos, although some people might comment on the scent."

I looked at the labels. They came from a company that caters to funeral homes. "I can see why. I'll have to thank her, next time I see her. Thanks, Mom."

"Thank you, Janelle. Have a good night."

"Goodnight, Mom." I armed the security system, then went down to the basement to see what was on TV.

It was a vampire movie. I watched, telling the screen everything that the filmmakers got wrong.
1111111111111.title: Back at Home

11111111111111.content:
The next afternoon, I awoke with the sensation that something was wrong. I couldn't place it right away, but something told me things were not as they should be (I mean, beyond the whole vampires-are-real-and-I-am-one thing).

When I sat up, I could see what was wrong: my bedroom door, which I had closed before turning in for the day, was open a crack. "Who's there?" I called.

"She's awake," I heard Mom say. Then she came to the door. "I'm sorry if we scared you, sweetie," she said.

Then, I heard Brad's voice say, "We scared her?!"

"I'm guessing somebody came in here?"

"Brad came looking for you," Mom explained. "He insisted on searching the whole house for you. When he went into your room, he found you dead to the world, in more ways than one. You... look a little different when you're asleep."

"Alright, let me take a shower, get dressed, and get something to drink, and I'll be right out." Damn damn damn damn damn damn damn. This was not how I wanted to explain things to him.

Once I was ready, I walked over to where Brad was sitting. "I look different, huh?"

Brad nearly jumped. "You... you looked dead."

I turned to Mom. "How much did you tell him?"

"After he screamed and fainted, I dragged him out of your room and put him on the couch. When he came to, I told him everything."

I turned back to Brad. "Any questions?"

"Why didn't you call me, or at least text me?"

"I didn't think this was the sort of situation I could or should handle in any way other than face to face. I mean, what would a text say: 'Undead; need human blood; more later'?"

"So,... what happens now? How does this affect our plans?"

"Well, college is out the window for me. I can't very well practice cheers in daylight, and the cafeteria doesn't cater to my dietary needs. So the next question is, how do you feel about it?"

"I... I don't know."

"That's okay. I don't mind giving you time. Lord knows I didn't rise with all the answers." I knelt before him and took his hand, only for him to take it back, reacting to my icy grip. "Just know that I'm still basically the same person, even if I'm a vampire now."

Brad got up and left. I hoped I would see him again.
11111111111111.title: Brad

111111111111111.content:
Once it was safely after dark, I asked Mom and Dad, "Is it okay if I go out tonight?"

"Where are you going?" Dad asked.

"Just to look around, check out the city at night."

"Alright. Be home by midnight."

"Can I come, too?" asked Courtney.

"Why would you want to go with her?" Mom asked.

"Just because. I'd like to see what's out there."

Mom and Dad looked at me, silently asking.

I sighed. "We're not getting out of the car, unless you have to use the little girl's room."

"Okay."

"Put your coat on."

******************************


We cruised the streets. I could almost feel the city around me. If I had been alone, I would have parked the car and looked around. In retrospect, I'm glad Courtney came with.

Because, as we headed down one street, I saw a familiar face. Four of them, in fact. I parked and got on the phone.

Finola picked up on the first ring. "Yes?"

"Finola, it's Janelle. I just saw Micah and his crew headed into a bar called Dennison's." I gave her the address.

"Good looking out, Janelle. We'll be there straightaway."

"Should I do anything else?"

"Yes: get away from there. This might get difficult." She hung up.

I started the car. "We need to get away," I told Courtney.

"I heard you talking," she said. "Those are the ones who turned you, aren't they? We should get them."

"No, we shouldn't. I'm not taking on four rogue vampires, especially not with you."

I drove around, and found an ice cream parlor that was still open. I ordered two sundaes, and we sat down so Courtney could eat. "You understand why I took us away from there?" I asked.

"No, I don't," she replied. "They hurt you. You should want to get back at them."

"Four against one? I don't like those odds."

"Two. I'd be with you."

"Court, I found out last night that I can't have children. That means that, if Mom and Dad ever become grandparents, it'll be from you. So I need to look out for you and any hypothetical offspring you may or may not have. That means, no playing Buffy the Vampire Slayer for you. Okay?"

Courtney's eyes were wide. "I never thought of it like that. You really can't have children?"

"I need blood too much to devote any of it to my uterus."

When Courtney finished her sundae, I gave her the one sitting in front of me.
111111111111111.title: That Night

choices: All My Friends in One Place
1111111111111111.content:
Before sunset on the night of my next lesson from Finola, she gave me a call. "I hope you are not averse to being put through your paces, colleen."

"There's a saying in competitive cheerleading," I replied: "'You win championships at practice; the competitions are just where you pick up the trophies.'"

"Very well. I shall expect similar dedication in the art of not getting yourself slain."

Not knowing what to expect, I prepared like it was cheerleading practice: I dressed to move, and packed a portable cooler with blood.

About half an hour after dark, the familiar black SUV pulled up. As I approached, Finola opened the front passenger door for me.

"How'd it go last week?" I asked.

"Precisely as I wanted," she replied. "Again, you have my thanks for helping me to protect humanity from their depredations.What's in the bag?"

"For cheer practice, we always had to bring water, to keep hydrated," I explained. "This isn't water, but I figured the same principle would apply."

"Indeed," she said. "However, I am prepared to offer more than your cheerleader instructors did." She indicated the back seat.

I looked. There were two young men with us. One of them was the one who had broken into the house. "Two of my thralls. One is for you tonight."

"Stupid question: What is a thrall?"

"These young men give me their blood as I need it," she explained. "In return, I consider turning them at a later date. As I said, one of them is available for your needs tonight."

I had never bitten anyone before. I didn't even know if I was ready to try. On the other hand, I would have to visit Dr. Kinski soon, and another source would extend my supply.

******************************


Finola wasn't kidding when she said I would be put through my paces. If I were still alive, I would have been sweating from all the physical activity I was putting in.

Finally, she called a break so we could feed. I went straight for my bag, but the man who broke into the house stepped between me and the bag. "I've got more than you need, miss," he said.

I'd be a liar if I said I never even considered it. In fact, I even took his hand and raised his arm to my lips. I could smell his blood within him...

But I put his arm back down. "I can't," I said. "Maybe it's the last gasp of a vegetarian life, or maybe my memories of that night are too strong right now. But I can't drink right from somebody. I'm sorry."

"There's no need to apologize, colleen. You have not offended me. I will say, however, that you won't want bagged blood once you have fed directly from a human being."

"Should I practice on animals?"

"The blood of animals doesn't nourish us as well as human blood, so you would need much more. The taste is off, as well. Stick with the bags, Janelle."
1111111111111111.title: My Next Training Session

11111111111111111.content:
I woke up in the middle of the afternoon the next day, the longest I'd slept thus far.

As I showered, I heard voices in the rec room, and I kept thinking that I'd forgotten something. Of course, the thing about forgetting something is that knowing you've forgotten it doesn't help you remember. So I finished getting ready, all the while listening to the whispers in the rec room, and wondering what had slipped my mind.

Finally, I opened my bedroom door, and everyone jumped out and yelled, "SURPRISE!"

Of course, them being there wasn't a surprise - I could hear and smell them, for God's sake - but what came next hit me right between the eyes.

They sang "Happy Birthday".

As Mom gave me a birthday hug, I whispered to her, "I forgot all about my birthday."

"Well," she replied, "a lot has happened in the past two weeks. But your friends all remembered."

Indeed they had. Dr. Kinski was there. Mindy and Zooey were there.

Brad was there.

He took me into his arms and kissed me. "That's an unusual taste," he said. "What is it?"

"Do you really want to know?" I asked.

"Probably not," he answered, and kissed me again.

The gifts were vampire-related. Dr. Kinski gave me a T-shirt with a picture of a cat with bat wings, and also brought me blood. Courtney gave me a vampire bat plushie. Brad gave me bat earrings and a matching bat necklace. Zooey gave me a T-shirt that said, "Careful, I Bite". Mindy gave me a hoodie decorated with a picture of a skull with a ribbon on it.

"Thank you all," I said. "I'm grateful for your gifts. I'm more grateful for your presence here today. I wouldn't have blamed any of you for suddenly remembering dental appointments."

As I watched them all enjoying cake and ice cream, it occurred to me that this ought to be my last birthday celebration.

Not because I couldn't have cake and ice cream, mind you, but because birthday parties didn't mean much when you were immortal. My friends and family would grow older, and I would stay the same age.

"How do you like the party?" Brad asked.

"It's nice," I replied. "I guess you've made up your mind about me?"

"You know it."

"Even though we can't go to college together, like we planned?"

"Haven't you heard? I'm going to college here in town. We may not be going to classes together, but we can still be together."

"Same here," Mindy said. "Friends."

"Best friends," said Zooey.
11111111111111111.title: All My Friends in One Place

111111111111111111.content:
Brad, Mindy, Zooey, and I decided that the night was right for seeing a movie. Brad graciously offered to drive us all, and off we went. We decided to see Expecting the Unexpected, the story of a teenage girl who found herself pregnant, even though she'd never had sex. It was an entertaining little movie, and we all enjoyed it.

On the way home, I said to the others, "Thanks, guys. I couldn't have asked for more for my last birthday party."

"Last birthday party?" asked Mindy. "What do you mean?"

"I mean that you don't need to celebrate the birthday of someone who will never get older. Do you really want to sit around wishing me a happy 65th birthday, when I won't look a day older than I do now?"

"Okay," Zooey said, "no more parties. But can we still get together and have a good time? And maybe sometimes, we get you something that you'd like, but you wouldn't normally buy for yourself?"

I thought that was only delaying the inevitable, but I said, "I'd like that."

When we got back to the house, Mindy and Zooey left for their homes, but Brad decided to stay for a while, and asked me if he could see my bedroom. I agreed.

It didn't take long to show him everything I had. Which was fine, because he quickly let me know what I'd half suspected; that he had something else in mind when he asked for permission to enter my bedroom.

And, frankly, I welcomed it. We kissed, passionately, removing our clothes as it felt right to do so. When we were both naked, I climbed into bed, he climbed on top of me, and our bodies became one.

Sex brought with it one reaction I wasn't expecting: as we built to a climax, I could hear, smell, feel the blood pulsing in his throat. It took everything I had not to bite him in the throes of my passion.

When it was over, he lay next to me. "How was it for you?" he asked.

"I almost bit you."

"Maybe someday I'll want you to."

"And what if I don't want to?"

"What if you do?" He kissed me. "I'm dating a vampire, it seems like something we should talk about."

"Okay. From now on, when we make love, we ask each other about biting, and I won't bite until we both agree."

"Agreed."

Later, he got dressed, and promised to call the next night.

When he left, I had two bags of blood.
111111111111111111.title: Movie Night

1111111111111111111.content:
It's a tradition in my family that, on the 4th of July, my extended family comes over for a cookout, with Dad manning the grill.

This was the first year I did not attend. Too much sun. So I sat in the basement, looking out the window at all the fun people were having.

It got kind of depressing, so I went into my room to get a bag from the fridge. Is blood consumption related to emotional states? I should ask Finola about that.

When I came back out into the rec room, my cousin, Anna, was there, with her baby girl. "Hi."

"Hi."

"Lindsay got hungry, so I came inside. And I remembered, there's someone else in the family on a liquid diet."

"Guess I was feeling pretty lonely." I put the bag in the rec room fridge.

"Would you like to hold her?" She held Lindsay out to me.

I demurred. "My touch isn't the warmest."

"She won't care. Go ahead. Take her."

I took her.

She stared up at me in wonder, then smiled.

I smiled back.

She laughed.

I laughed, and said to Anna, "Nobody's ever laughed at my fangs before." I handed her back. "You're lucky to have her."

She smiled wistfully. "You're the first person to call me that since the stick turned pink. I guess I do feel lucky."

Then, Mindy and Zooey came in. "We thought you might be feeling kinda left out," Mindy said. "Are we interrupting?"

"Joining, more like. Anna, these are my friends, Mindy and Zooey. They're together. Girls, this is Anna and her daughter, Lindsay."

The four of us spent the afternoon in the basement, hanging out. Four outcasts who decided to be outcasts together.

Oh, you wanted to know about what I thought of the fireworks show? Well, they set off fireworks they purchased themselves, and I was glad I was in the basement. Fireworks and vampire hearing are not a happy combination.
1111111111111111111.title: The 4th of July

11111111111111111111.content:
Before my training session began, I asked Finola, "Does how we feel play a part in how much blood we drink?"

She cocked an eyebrow. "What brings this on?"

"On the 4th of July, I was all set to have an extra bag, because my family were having fun in the sun without me. Then, somebody said hello, and I didn't feel like having that bag."

"Well, colleen, as you've noticed, your mind can tell you that you're hungry when you're not. I would say that's what's at play here. Now, on to your lessons."

As usual, Finola gave me a workout. However, I was doing much better than I had when I started so many weeks ago. Once or twice, I think I even surprised her.

When we took a break to feed, though, she was the one who surprised me. "Good enough, I think, Janelle."

"Thank you. Good enough for what?"

"I agreed to give you the training you need to make it in this world as a vampire. I've done that."

"Oh."

"You don't seem too happy about that."

"Well, our sparring sessions were something to look forward to. Now, it'll just be sitting around the house at night - like I don't do enough of that in the afternoon - or driving around town, just seeing where the night takes me. My girlfriends can only see so many movies a week."

"I think I know what's troubling you, colleen: Now that you know what you can do, you don't want to sit around and do nothing. You need a job. Trouble is, a lot of places don't keep vampire-friendly hours."

"So what can I do?"

"I'm on good terms with the master vampire of this city. I'll put in some calls, and we'll see what sort of an occupation we can line up for you. Goodnight, Janelle."
11111111111111111111.title: What Can I Do?

111111111111111111111.content:
The next night, my phone rang. It was Finola. "Yes?"

"I have two possible employment opportunities for you, Janelle," she said.

"Let's hear them."

"A private investigator offers an apprenticeship. You would have the freedom to turn down cases that required daylight activity, and your senses would give you information no other detective could match."

"Sounds interesting. What's the second offer?"

"The Knightley Cab Company needs a late-night driver. You wouldn't have to show up before sunset, and you would be home before sunrise. The master vampire of this city owns it, so they would be willing to ignore the fact that you're underage, as well as the fact that your last physical was stamped 'D.O.A.'"

My late-night driving sessions had given me a good working knowledge of the city streets. "I think I'd like to give being a taxi driver a try," I said.

"Excellent." She gave me the contact information. "Call to set up an appointment for an interview. A mere formality, but one that will leave a good impression. Besides, you will learn what all the job entails. Goodnight, Janelle."

I called the cab company, then went upstairs. "I've got an interview tomorrow night, with a cab company."

"That should earn you a bit of money," Dad said.

"And you'd be safer than any living driver," Mom added.
111111111111111111111.title: A Job Offer

1111111111111111111111.content:
The next night, I arrived on time for my job interview. I chuckled privately as the words job interview with the vampire went through my mind. Approaching a woman in a suit, I said, "Hi. My name's Janelle Lee. I'm here for my interview."

The woman nodded. "Loretta Hamilton. Everybody calls me Ham. Let's go into my office."

In her office, she pointed at the chair in front of her desk, then sat on the other side. "What's your story, Janelle Lee?"

"I beg your pardon?"

"I crawl out of bed, and this guy in a suit that cost more than my car tells me he works for Mr. Ducarla. Then he tells me Ducarla owns the cab company, so I work for him, too. Then he tells me that this kid fresh out of high school wants to be a cab driver, and I am going to ignore her age, take a pass on her physical, and hire her right off the street. So, my question is, why does the richest man in town want you to drive a cab?"

"I don't know," I replied. "The other day, I mentioned to a friend that I needed something to do. Last night, she gives me a call, saying she's got two opportunities for me. I picked one, and here I am."

"So it's not you, it's a friend. Well, maybe I have to hire you, but I can and will fire your ass if you can't cut it. Let me show you around."

She led me to the garage. "These are our machines. Before your fare steps inside, this will give them their first impression. Showing up late tells them we're unreliable, and they'll call someone else. Then we have to cut back, which means you're out of a job."

She opened a door. "We'll pay to keep our cars street legal, but keeping the interior clean is on you. Also, damage the equipment too many times, and you're gone."

"Do you know a Stephen Lee? Because this sounds a lot like what he told me when I started learning to drive."

She led me to a minivan. "This is what you'll be driving. Too bad if it's not up to your standards."

"I learned how to drive in a minivan. It's no problem."

"Show up on time. Keep your cab clean. Obey the traffic laws. Be courteous to your fares. In the age of Uber, that includes giving them bottled water and snacks. Those are supplied by you."

"Got it."

Ham had me fill out my hack license, took my picture, and said, "See you tomorrow night."

******************************


When I got home, Mindy and Zooey were there. "What's up, girlfriend?"

"You're looking at the new driver for the Knightley Cab Company."
1111111111111111111111.title: The Knightley Cab Company

11111111111111111111111.content:
After I woke up, Mom met me in the rec room. "I got you some bottled water and granola bars," she said, "since you said you'd need them. Also, this." She handed me a stainless steel water bottle. "Less conspicuous than drinking blood out of a plastic bag."

"Good call," I said.

When the sun went down, I loaded my supplies into my car and drove to the cab company. There, I checked in with the dispatcher. "Which one's my ride?"

"804," Ham replied, "all gassed up and ready. You call me every time you head out on a fare, when you want to go on a meal break, when you have to use the little girl's room, and when you're ready to hit the streets again."

"Understood." With that, I drove off onto the city streets at night.

My first fare was a group of businessmen. They didn't tell me their names, but it didn't matter, because they all looked alike. I took them to their apartment buildings, and they each tipped me $100. Needless to say, I didn't mind driving them around.

I didn't expect anyone else to be so generous, and they weren't. Some were good tippers, but there was this one jerk who said, "You want a tip? I don't give money away. That's why I've got so much of it." I made a note of his description, so I could avoid picking him up in the future. To him, tipping was giving money away; to me, it was a chunk of my salary.

******************************


About halfway through my shift, I saw a row of cabs parked outside Nouri's, an all-night coffee shop. Figuring out that the drivers were taking a break, I called mine in and joined them. "Hi," I said. "The name's Lee."

"What brings you out here so late, Lee?" asked a man of Middle Eastern descent.

"Just started driving," I said, pointing a thumb at my cab. "You guys have been doing it for a while. Figured I could maybe get some advice from you."

They gave me a few life hacks, and I also learned about their lives. Greene was a veteran, losing a leg in Iraq. Kaptan was originally from Turkey, and was the breadwinner for a family of seven. Blasko had been a cabbie longer than any of the others.

******************************


I got home an hour before sunrise. Mom was already awake. "How was your first night?"

"All in all," I replied, "I think I'm going to like this gig."
11111111111111111111111.title: First Night on the Job

111111111111111111111111.content:
The next night, I got robbed.

I didn't expect to be robbed - though maybe I should have, given that I drive around with a box full of cash - but I came up with a pretty decent course of action on the fly. For the benefit of any vampires reading this who are thinking of becoming cab drivers, here is what I did:

1) Remain calm. You don't want to go off half-cocked while you're the center of this guy's attention. Remember, not only don't you want to tip him off to the existence of vampires, but cleaning the cab interior is your job. Do you want to deal with powder burns and blood splatter? Didn't think so.

2) Cooperate fully. For the reasons stated above, you need to play this like you're a mortal who would be hurt by a bullet to the face.

3) As you watch which way he runs, pull the cab over and park. You wouldn't want to get a ticket while you're following the next steps. Those things cost money. Plus, the courts run in daylight hours, so you can't plead it down.

4) Get out and run the little bastard down. You can outrun them, so they haven't gotten far.

5) Kick the robber's ass. I beat the perp like a government mule. If you're inclined to draining them dry, so be it. Just remember to call the cleaning crew to take care of the body before anyone sees it.

6) Collect the cashbox and run back to your cab. Eyes on the prize.

******************************


Later, at Nouri's, Greene was buying, and he offered me a cup of coffee.

I shook my head. "Sensitive stomach." Holding up the bottle, I added, "My doctor gives me this stuff to keep me going. It's all I can eat or drink without it doubling back on me." All of which was true. I just didn't mention that my doctor was a coroner, or that the contents of the bottle came in varieties like B-positive and O-negative.

That was good enough for Greene, though. He drank to my health, and I to his.
111111111111111111111111.title: Challenges

1111111111111111111111111.content:
It's true what they say: Some people will tell a cab driver anything. Maybe it's the whole I'll-never-see-you-again vibe we've got going on, but we're privy to the inner lives of so many individuals who you wouldn't look twice at. Here are some of the things I heard in my first week as a professional driver:

"I could have had her. I wanted her. And she wanted me. But my folks didn't like her. 'Not our sort, dear.' So I married someone else. Five years, and she's binging and purging, and whether I touch her or not depends on astrology or some shit. Let me tell you: If you ever find the one, you hold on like your life depends on it. Damn straight your sanity will."


******************************


"Love conquers all, they say. No, it doesn't. It doesn't conquer his hold on your joint account, where your money is. It doesn't conquer his jealousy if you talk to anyone who isn't him. And it damn sure doesn't conquer his fists if you ever put one goddamn toe out of line. Eventually, you start looking for something that will conquer his ass. And here's hoping you're not seven months knocked up when you find it. If it's not too late for you, remember: When you look at the world through rose-colored glasses, red flags just look like flags."


******************************


"Everything seems so simple, right up until you've actually got to do it. Everybody says, if it's them or me, I'm looking out for numero uno. Even if it means killing somebody, they say. Well, every now and then, somebody finds himself in that him-or-me-somebody's-got-to-die situation. And let me tell you, the first sentence to run through your mind will be, Well, what's so special about me, that I should live and he shouldn't?"


******************************


"Not all of us are God's creatures. Some of us are demons from the pit of Hell. They wear our faces, but they don't live as we do. To exist, they must take from us. And I'll bet you, if I told you that I knew how to find them and send them to God's Judgment, you'd probably say I was crazy."


******************************


"The club scene's changed since those guys disappeared."

"Yeah, it got better."

"I heard somebody killed them."

"Well, I heard those guys killed a whole bunch of people, so acceptable losses."
1111111111111111111111111.title: Fare Stories

11111111111111111111111111.content:
I pulled in at Nouri's, and found the guys had started a good old-fashioned bull session. Blasko was first, telling us of how he had Leonardo DiCaprio in his cab. I'm inclined to believe him, because he told the star that he had no idea who he was.

Kaptan was next. "I pick up this old couple. You think nothing would happen, but they start going at it, right in my back seat, with me driving. I was good with ladies when I was young, and they put me to shame."

"What did you do?" I asked. "About the older couple, I mean."

"I see cop car next to me. So I ask cops, Is it okay if they do this in my cab? And cops get on loud speaker, they say, You, get off of man." We all laughed.

"I picked up these two guys at the bank," Greene said, "and they gave me directions to a specific place. Then, I found out the police were looking for two guys who robbed a bank, and guess which one. So I drove the police right to them."

"How about you, Lee?" Kaptan asked. "You got good story to tell?"

I wasn't about to tell them about how I beat up a robber, since I was supposed to be as petite as I looked, so I said, "Sorry, I haven't been driving long enough for any good stories."

"Well, there's gotta be something you can share," Greene said. "Maybe something from before you got your hack license."

I shook my head. "There's a story, but not one you guys want to hear."

"Now I must know," Blasko said.

I sighed. "It was right after graduation, and I mean right after. I snuck into this underground rave, and I bumped right into the guy who ran it. But he acted cool, so I thought I'd be okay, you know? Then he slipped something into my drink, and he called three of his friends over. They did what they wanted with me, then they left me for dead in the alley."

Which goes to show that vampires can also kill the mood. "Told you you didn't want to hear it."

Greene put a hand on my bottle. "These rave guys," he said, "you get a good look at 'em? Could you tell me where they were?"

From the looks on the other two guys' faces, they were thinking the same thing.

"They've been taken care of," I promised. "And I'd appreciate it if I didn't hear this story anywhere else, okay? I just want to move on."

"Nobody will hear it from us," Greene promised. "If anyone else gives you any trouble, let us know."

"We cabbies stick together," Blasko added. "Anyone gives one of us trouble, we give them real trouble."

"Thanks, guys. I mean that." Someday, I knew, it would be necessary to let these guys know that I was a vampire.
11111111111111111111111111.title: Drivers' War Stories

111111111111111111111111111.content:
For my first night off, I went to a movie with Mindy and Zooey. "What's being a cab driver like?" Mindy asked.

"Like any other job," I replied, "the customer makes it or breaks it. Some people tip better than others; some people make a mess in the back seat, which I have to clean up; and some people are just jerks."

"Is it true," Zooey asked, "that cab drivers turn on the meter before you get in?"

"Sometimes. If I have to drive out a long way to pick you up, I'll turn the meter on along the way. Otherwise, that drive - and the gas I burn getting there - are on me."

"And how about Ub- "

"We do not discuss The App Which Must Not Be Named," I said in a loud voice.

"Okay. Pick up any celebrities?"

"Not yet. I'll let you know the afternoon after."

"What goes a long way with drivers?"

"If you need to throw up, tell us. We won't laugh at you. Throwing up in the car sucks for both of us: You have to pay a $200 sanitation fee, and I have to clean it up."

"Is there anything good about dealing with a bad customer?"

"The A-hole button."

"What's that?"

"Technically, it's the extra passenger button, and it's supposed to tell the meter that there's more than two passengers getting in. But sometimes, I use it to make some jerk literally pay for being a jerk. I had this one guy, everything he said, if it wasn't sexist, it was racist. So I warn him, if he doesn't watch his tongue, it's going to cost him. He keeps it up, and I start hitting the A-hole button. By the time we get to where he's going, the meter reads that I drove 12 people on his dime."

******************************


The movie was The Height of Summer, about a teenage girl who finds herself growing into a giantess. Pretty cool.
111111111111111111111111111.title: My Nights Off

1111111111111111111111111111.content:
When Brad called to ask me out on a date, I was over the moon. I mean, I knew that a mortal/vampire relationship would have issues, but I loved him, and wanted to make it work.

"Wanna go to your favorite Thai place?" he asked.

"I can't eat food," I replied.

"Oh, right. Hey, wanna go dancing? There's a new club that just opened, the cover charge is low, and the drinks - "

"The last time I went clubbing, I woke up in the morgue. Besides, there's only one thing I can drink, and nobody has it on tap."

"Oh, right. Wait! I've got it!"

"You've got what?"

"It's a surprise. Just put a couple bags in a cooler, and be ready when I show up at sunset."

How could I say no? At the very least, my curiosity was piqued.

******************************


Twilight was giving way to night when Brad arrived. He kissed me, then took my cooler and threw it in the trunk of his car. I saw a boom box and two blankets before he closed it. "Can I at least get a hint?" I asked

"Sure," he replied. "We'll be alone there, because everyone else will have left." With that, we began the drive.

I figured it out when I saw the sign welcoming us to New Jersey. "If I had a pulse," I said, "you would have just sent it racing."

Sure enough, we arrived at the beach on the Jersey shore. As promised, we were alone, since other beachgoers actually want to expose themselves to the sun's rays. We spread out the blankets, turned on the music, and danced in the moonlight.

Later, we made love, and I sank my fangs into a bag of blood instead of Brad's neck.

It was after midnight when we returned home, but that was a bigger deal for him than for me.
1111111111111111111111111111.title: Date Night with Brad

11111111111111111111111111111.content:
Back in my taxi, I decided to let my friends know the truth about me. I didn't know for sure how they would react, but I had a good feeling.

At Nouri's, over their coffee and my blood, I said, "I can talk to you guys about anything, right?"

"Anything at all," Greene replied. "What's on your mind, Lee?"

"There's something I want to tell you guys. It's going to sound crazy, but I swear it's the truth."

"You are a vampire."

The guys turned to look at Blasko, as stunned as I was.

"I am," I said. "How did you know?"

"I am from the Carpathian Mountains, Miss Lee. At the age when you learned about talking rabbits and rich ducks, I learned about vampires." He indicated my bottle. "Your blood, yes?"

"How long have you known?"

"The first night you came, I thought you might not be breathing as often as you should need to. I knew it when you refused any food or drink. Any other condition, you could drink bottled water."

"You didn't out me. Why?"

He smiled. "I said I learned about vampires, yes? That includes learning what they are like: Like us."

Greene turned to me. "So, when you said you were attacked by four guys,... "

"That happened. I just didn't say they were vampires. And they did leave me for dead: so dead, I got to meet the coroner at her job. They didn't mean to turn me, it just happened. I figured I should tell you guys before the weather gets too chilly, and you started wondering why you couldn't see my breath."

Greene smiled. "Well, if you've earned Blasko's respect, that says a lot about you, young lady. Like I said before, we stick together."
11111111111111111111111111111.title: The Guys Surprise Me

111111111111111111111111111111.content:
A couple nights later, I picked up this college-age guy. He was skinny, unshaven, and smelled like he'd never bathed in his life. Please don't stink up my car, I thought.

He asked me to take him to the other side of town, but, halfway there, he asked, "Can we stop here for a while?"

"If you want," I replied. "Just remember, the meter's running."

He pressed a gun into the back of my head. "I'm not worried about the meter."

"I guess not," I said, already thinking of how to turn this around.

Once we were out of the cab, I spun around and took the gun.

Seemingly unfazed, the guy whipped out a crucifix and stuck it in my face. "You won't win this night, demon!"

I took the crucifix out of his hand. "You've been watching too many movies."

Up pulled a late-model car. "Friend of yours?" I asked Cross Boy.

A man in his thirties stepped out. "What seems to be the problem?"

"Everything's under control, stranger," I said.

"Name's Mike Sutherland," he said. "Private investigator. I'm a thrall of Finola's."

That last part got my attention. "What's on her mind?"

"Scuttlebutt was that there was a would-be slayer in town. She asked me to keep an eye on you."

"Sounds like Stinky, here. Buffy, he ain't."

"I'll take care of him. Need anything else?"

"Yeah, he owes me money."

Mike handed me a $100 bill. " With Finola's compliments."
111111111111111111111111111111.title: My First Slayer

1111111111111111111111111111111.content:
My last fare of the night was a familiar face. "I understand you met your first slayer," Finola said.

"The deadliest thing about him was his body odor," I replied. "Took me half an hour to make my cab not smell like a toilet."

"I'll compensate you, colleen. How is it working out, apart from that?"

"Never a dull night. Last night, I got to use the Jedi mind trick."

"Jedi... Ah, yes, that's the name you gave our power of hypnosis. What were the circumstances?"

"I drive this wealthy hotshot around, and, when we get to the place, he says, 'Here's how I got rich: I never give money away.' Well, tips count for most of my take-home pay, so I look him dead in the eyes and say, 'You will give me a tip.' His eyes glaze over, and he says, 'I will give you a tip.' Then he reaches into his wallet and pulls out a $100 bill."

"I'm giving you some information on online colleges, Janelle. In case you ever decide that driving a taxi is not something you want to spend eternity doing."

"So far, I like it fine. But I'll keep the information, since you haven't led me wrong."

She gave me the information when I dropped her off. She wasn't kidding about compensating me, either: she gave me a $500 tip.
1111111111111111111111111111111.title: Online Colleges

11111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The next afternoon, Courtney asked me, "How's the cab driver thing going?"

"Good nights and bad," I replied. "Just last night, I got to tangle with my very first slayer."

"WHAT? How can you be so calm? Somebody wanted you dead - and to stay dead!"

"But I'm not staying dead, am I? Finola put a tail on me, just in case."

"She knew he was out there, and let you deal with it yourself?!"

"I have to learn sometime, sis. Besides, if he was half as dangerous as he thought he was, Finola wouldn't have put a tail on me: She'd have told me to call in sick until they had him off the streets."

"I still don't trust her."

"Do you trust me, and my judgment?"

"Of course."

"Well, I trust her, so, by extension, so do you."
11111111111111111111111111111111.title: Courtney Has Questions

choices: Forget you heard the name Van Helsing.
111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The next night, at Nouri's, I had just finished my shift and was resting with the other cab drivers when a strange man walked in. He was of average height, but well built, with black hair and piercing green eyes. "Coffee, regular," he said to the barista.

He put down a stack of bills and nudged it towards Greene, who was sitting between the strange man and me. "Looking for a ride?" Flatly, Greene asked.

"Looking for an old friend." Calmly, the man said. "She goes by the name of Finola, and has two associates named Llewellyn and Blackwell."

I held up a newspaper I was looking at, hiding the fact I had winced, as Greene replied, "They don't sound familiar, but I'll keep my ears open." He pushed the money back. "Why are you so interested in these three that it's worth a few grand just to ask about them?"

"I have the money to spend." Calmly, the man replied. "I'll leave the tip and my card.... the name is Van Helsing... John Van Helsing."

With that, the man drank his coffee before walking out. After he was gone, Greene turned to me. "I take it you know the three he's looking for."

I gave a single nod. "They are sort of helping me sort out who and what I am." Whispering, I replied. "Other than that, it's best you don't know."

Greene nodded. "I know more than you may think, but we'll leave it at that."

After arriving back home, I phoned Finola and told her of the strange man who called himself John Van Helsing. "His family have hunted vampires for generations." Flatly, Finola explained. "He is the last of that clan. We will deal with it tomorrow night." Her voice then turned dark. "It would be in your best interest if you..."
111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Trouble for the Guys

1111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
I gulped. "What should I do instead?" I asked.

"I highly recommend that you remain home," Finola replied. "That way, when you call in sick tomorrow night, it will look like you really are sick."

"Isn't there more I can - "

"I have several vampires and thralls on my staff, colleen," Finola said with a sigh. "Please don't make me send someone to babysit you, when there are so many other things they could be doing."

I got the message. "Alright. I'll be a good little girl and stay home. You have my word. May I ask a favor?"

"What is it?"

"Please, if you're too busy to do it yourself, send someone to Nouri's Coffee Shop, and assure a group of three cabbies that I will be alright. Their names are Greene, Kaptan, and Blasko. Greene has a prosthetic leg, Kaptan is Turkish, and Blasko is an older gentleman from the Old Country."

"You're worried about them?"

"Cabbies stick together. If they think I'm in some kind of trouble, they'll walk right into the thick of it."

"I'll see to it that they are assured of your safety and well-being, Janelle. Good morning."

******************************


After I woke up, I called Ham and told her I was sick. Courtney walked in on me during the call. "I thought vampires didn't get sick," she said, after I hung up.

"We don't," I confirmed. "But she doesn't know I'm a vampire, and calling in sick is a good reason for me not to be driving around New York City tonight."

"What's going on?"

"Remember yesterday, when I told you that Finola wouldn't let me out if there was a dangerous vampire slayer in town?"

"Yeah."

"Does the last name Van Helsing conjure up any special images in your mind?"

Courtney hugged me. "Are you gonna be okay?"

"I'll be fine, Court. He wants something from Finola. I'm just staying out of the way. Wanna stay up late and watch movies with me? You pick."

"Okay."
1111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Take tomorrow night off.

11111111111111111111111111111111112.content:
Needless to say, with Courtney picking the movies, it was a vampire movie marathon. Mercifully, she had outgrown the sparkly vampire flicks, so I was spared images of centuries-old vamps making doe eyes at unexpressive teenage girls. But she still had plenty of heroic bloodsucker movies, so that was what we watched.

Even though the whole idea was to stay up late, Courtney conked out before midnight. By that time, I was hooked. Oh, sure, I could have blamed it on keeping it going in case she woke up again. But the fact remains, I carried her upstairs, I tucked her in, I kissed her goodnight, then I went back down and kept watching.

That's what I was doing when my phone rang. "Hello?"

"Janelle Lee?"

"You have me at a disadvantage, Mr... ?"

"My name is Bergin. I am a thrall to Finola. There are three obstreperous gentlemen here who insist that they speak with you."

"Alright. Put Greene on."

The next voice I heard was Greene's. "Are you alright, Lee? I want to hear it from you."

"I'm sitting at home, wondering why Moonlight was only on for one season. Other than that, I'm the same as when you saw me last. You guys?"

"If you're okay, then we're okay. What can you tell us about the guy who has you curled up at home?"

"All I know is the name Van Helsing. You know what that could mean for me. His business is with Finola, so all I should need to do is stay out of it. Which means you need to stay out of it, okay? Finola can take care of herself, trust me."

"I know she can, kid. It's you I worry about. You're a bit on the young side, after all. I'd never forgive myself, even if the boss did."

"Your boss? You work for a different company, why would your boss care about me?"

"You and I have another boss, outside the taxi business, Lee. Take care of yourself." On that enigmatic note, he hung up.
11111111111111111111111111111111112.title: The Cabbies Call

111111111111111111111111111111111121.content:
About an hour before sunrise, Finola called. "You can go back to work tomorrow, colleen," she said. "Van Helsing will be working with us."

"Really?" I asked. "I never pictured anyone named Van Helsing being vamp-friendly."

"He and I have made an arrangement," she explained. "He will be helping us reduce the number of rogues out there, so the Masquerade can be preserved."

"Finola , I'd like to ask you a question, if I may."

"What is it?"

"Greene said he and I had the same boss. What was he talking about?"

"To speak for Mr. Greene is not my place. As for you, however, I can tell you much. You know that the cab company you work for is owned by Mr. Ducarla, correct?"

"Yeah."

"And you know that Mr. Ducarla is the reason you work there?"

"Ham mentioned that when I went in for the job interview. Neither of us knew why he wanted me to drive a cab."

"His name is spelled D-U-C-A-R-L-A, Janelle. Why don't you take a moment and unscramble the letters?"

I did. "Holy shit! The Dracula? But he died at the end of the book!"

"Stoker got a lot of things wrong when he wrote that story. I should know: I was there when it happened. Sometime ,when we both have an evening to spare, I'll tell you all about it. Good morning, colleen."
111111111111111111111111111111111121.title: An Arrangement

1111111111111111111111111111111111211.content:
I returned to work that night, and my break couldn't come soon enough. Once I got to Nouri's, I went right up to Greene. "Is there someplace we can talk privately?" I asked.

Greene took me around to the side of the building. "What's on your mind?"

"You've known more about me than you've let on, and I would like to know how you heard."

He unbuttoned his shirt and showed me a tattoo on the side of his neck. "See that? That glyph marks me as thrall to a vampire. In my case, I am thrall to the city's master vampire. He currently goes by Mr. Ducarla, but I'm sure you know who he is."

"I do. If I may ask, how'd you get here?"

"I was enthralled as a young man. After 9/11, I joined the army, and lost my leg. My master said that, according to the rules, I couldn't receive the Dark Gift, but I could still be of service. Cabbies hear and see everything that happens around town, so I could be his eyes and ears. Now, what can you tell me about John Van Helsing?"

"Well, he and Finola have come to an agreement. He's going to help cut down the number of rogues operating out there."

"Okay. I wonder which rogues he'll be taking on?"

"What do you mean? What other kind of rogue could there be?"

"Come on, Lee. You know vampires exist. Did you honestly think that their age-old enemies were fictitious?"
1111111111111111111111111111111111211.title: Greene

11111111111111111111111111111111112111.content:
The next afternoon, Courtney came down to hang out with me. "Court," I asked, "you know a lot about vampires, right?"

"I used to think I did," she replied. "But a lot of the stuff I thought I knew isn't true. You're proof of that."

"Oh. I wanted to ask you something, though."

"I guess I can give it a shot."

"Who or what would you say were the age-old enemies of vampires?"

"Not counting slayers? Probably werewolves."

"Really? How'd that happen?"

"From what I've read, wealthy vamps used werewolves for security. Emphasis on used. After while, the arrangement soured, and the two sides fought each other for centuries. Of course, that's died down considerably. Be hard to maintain the Masquerade in the middle of a war."

"So, there's a cleaning crew for werewolves?"

"Not like the one for vampires, I'm sure. Oh, agents of the regional alpha walk around in daylight, but they'd need outside help when the moon is full."

"Humans."

"Maybe vampires, too, in a limited capacity. Just because vampires are accustomed to subtlety."

"I guess a howling beast tearing people apart and eating them isn't very subtle."

"Yeah. Hey, I just thought of something."

"What?"

"Remember that wild dog attack the night of the senior prom?"

"I remember coming home and finding Mom and Dad worrying about me because of it."

"Well, what if it wasn't a wild dog? What if that was a werewolf?"

"Gee, I hope not. That would mean the girl who survived is a werewolf now. That can't be a picnic to deal with."

Courtney shrugged. "At least she can get a summer job. Just one that lets her be home before dark.'

"She'd be almost as restricted in her choice of college as I am. Being a werewolf and dorm life doesn't sound like a winning combination."
11111111111111111111111111111111112111.title: Talking to Courtney

111111111111111111111111111111111121111.content:
On my next night off, Finola came by, bringing blood bags and a story or two. "So what's the real story of Dracula?" I asked.

"The master sought to move to London," she replied. "Van Helsing, a dedicated slayer, sought to destroy him. That much was true. I don't know if Stoker changed the rest deliberately, or if Van Helsing sought to make himself and his allies look better."

"You said you were there," I said. "Which character was based on you?"

"I think the closest was Mina. However, I was not some attorney's wife. I believe the current terminology is sex worker. I had gone to London to become an actress, but my skills did not impress anyone. And I was rubbish at cooking and cleaning, which, at the time, left me with precisely one marketable skill."

"So how did you get involved in the story?"

"They brought me and my twin sister along to... service them."

"Sounds awful."

"That wasn't the worst of it. The young doctor, called Seward in the novel, brought the latest wonder drug with him: cocaine. What he didn't know, of course, was the effect of cocaine on a man's... capabilities, let's say. It also made them short-tempered, which made them more inclined to take out their frustrations on my sister and myself.

"Needless to say, when they finally reached Castle Dracula, they were hardly in a fit state to take on the King Vampire. The Englishmen and the Texan died quickly. Van Helsing survived by turning tail and running. My sister and I were freed, and we welcomed the Dark Gift when our time came."

"It sounds like I would have, too." I changed the subject. "What can you tell me about werewolves?"

"Werewolves? Werewolves and vampires fought bitterly for centuries. Now, though, we have a truce in place, the better to safeguard the Masquerade. If you see any werewolves, leave them alone, unless they attack you. That's all you need to do."

"How will I know them?"

"You'll know them by sight and scent, as they will know you. And then you will leave them strictly alone."
111111111111111111111111111111111121111.title: Talking with Finola

1111111111111111111111111111111111211111.content:
The next night was a date night, and Brad and I decided to see a movie. After all, in the darkness of a theater, nobody would notice that one person wasn't munching on popcorn or sipping soda.

I was in the lobby, waiting for Brad to buy his snacks, when someone said, "Janelle Lee?"

I turned. It was a couple of girls I vaguely recognized from school. Not wanting to make it super awkward, I stuck with generalities until I jogged my memory. "How are you guys doing? Fancy running into you here."

The girl with the rainbow pin turned to the other. "Told you she wouldn't know our names." Turning back to me, she said, "Sarah Patterson and Elisabeth Brooks."

I nodded. "Now I know you two. You were always hanging out with Tasha Lyall. What's she been up to?"

"Staying out of trouble," her voice said. "You?"

"The same," I said, turning to speak to Tasha. Once I saw her, I froze for a moment. Tasha didn't look the same as she did in high school, and not just because she had lost weight and her glandular problems cleared up.

Tasha was hairy.

I don't mean her hair was long and bushy. I mean her face was covered with an almost translucent coat of fur. Also, her ears were pointed, and, when she smiled, I saw that she had fangs. Taking a quick sniff of the air, I caught the scent of a wild animal in the theater lobby.

That's when I realized what was going on: Tasha Lyall was a werewolf. And, the way she was looking at me, she now knew I was a vampire.

The two of us exchanged stiff pleasantries, but it was a relief for me when Brad came with his snacks. I don't think either one of us was ready to test the truce.
1111111111111111111111111111111111211111.title: I See a Werewolf

1111111111111111111111111111111111211111.content:
A couple of nights later, Ham told me I was to take a waitress home from Lycaon, a rather snobby restaurant. To my surprise, it was Tasha.

Once we were on our way, she said, "So you're a cab driver, now."

"And you're a waitress," I replied. "How's the food? Tourists are always asking for recommendations."

"The food is wonderful," she said, "and I'm not just saying that because they pay me the medium-sized bucks. For people of more modest means, give Manganiello's a try."

Then she changed the subject to what had been on her mind since we saw each other at the movies. "How long have you been a vampire?"

"You remember graduation night, when I went off to dance the night away? I snuck into this underground rave, four guys bit me, and I woke up in the morgue." With the ice broken, I asked, "When did you become a werewolf?"

"Prom night," she replied. "The guy who took me wanted to dance with someone else, so I went home early. I was walking through the park, and I saw this beast eating somebody. It attacked me, and I used my pepper spray on it. It ran off, but not before it bit me. As I recovered, I realized I was going through some changes. Then this guy shows up, says he's a werewolf, and he was the one who attacked me, so now I'm a werewolf, too." After a pause, she asked, "What do I look like to you?"

"Truth? You're covered with fur, and you smell like an animal. What do I look like?"

"You look like death warmed over, and you smell even worse."

We drove in silence for a while, then I said, "I envy you."

"You envy me? What for?"

"You can walk in the sunshine like it's no big deal. You can eat food. You can have children. All that was taken away from me."

"You can run around every night of the month. No matter when, you always think like yourself."

"Twilight made us look stupid."

"Trust me, nobody looked good in Twilight."

As we pulled up to her house, I asked, "Would you like for me to make sure you get in safely?"

"Not necessary. Thanks for the ride." She tipped me $10.

"I hope your car is out of the shop soon."

"My car is fine," she said with a smile. "But you and I got to talk this way."
1111111111111111111111111111111111211111.title: Tasha Is a Fare

1111111111111111111111111111111111211111.content:
The next afternoon, Courtney and I were hanging out in the rec room, like we usually did, when both Mom and Dad came down. "Look at the two of you," Dad said. "I don't think I've seen you spend this much time together before."

"And to think," Mom said, "none of us would be here, if it weren't for that course."

"What course was that?" Courtney asked.
