11112211121121112111213222.content:
"I am ready for you, Janelle." Serious, Mike said. "The sooner you start, the sooner you will be ready for your first job."

Sighing, I walked into the room Mike pointed to, only to gasp as I was greeted with a literal mountain of books. I threw Mike a questioning look, only to be given an almost sinister grin. "I want you to read and memorize every last page, young lady." Smiling, he said. "Knowledge is the key to power."

"You're joking, right?" Scoffing, I said. "Do you have any idea how long it will take for me to memorize all of this?"

"Dhampirs live up to four hundred years." Calmly, Mike said. "You have the time." His grin returned. "You must learn patience before moving on to the actual studies."

With that said, Mike quietly left the room. Judging by the grin on his face, I knew he was enjoying this. I turned to the huge stack of books and sighed. Only upon opening the first book, I realized that I had read the entire first page by merely glancing at it, and turned to the second, only to learn that I had read that just as fast.

"What...?!" confused, I blurted out.

To my surprise and inner delight, I had read the entire book in less than a minute. What was more surprising was that I could recite the entire book, page for page, as if I had read it a thousand times. As I moved from book to book, I realized a new power of the vampire. Speed reading and instant memorization. "This is incredible!" Smiling, I said to myself. "At this rate, I'll be done in a half hour."

I moved through the books at an impressive rate, and was done in half an hour, as I had predicted. As I closed the last book, Mike walked in, smiling. "I take it you found that you can speed read as a dhampir." Calmly, he said.

"It was incredible." Smiling, I said. "I didn't know I had it in me."

"One of the many powers of the vampire and dhampir." Calmly, Mike said. "Now that you had memorized all of the books, you are ready to move on to the basics." He became serious. "The advanced classes are more, shall we say... involved."

"What do you mean?" Worried, I asked. "More books..."

"Speak with authority!" Firmly, Mike snapped. "You are a dhampir, and the direct descendant of Dracula himself, not a delicate human rose!"

That irritated me, though I jumped slightly at his voice, and I snapped back, "Even roses have thorns!"

Mike scoffed. "Then show them when you speak to me." Serious, he said. "A dhampir and vampire are confident in all aspects of their lives." He sighed. "A timid anything is not taken seriously in our line of work. You must show you have confidence in all that you do and say."

"This is all new territory to me." Pouting, i said. "I'm at a disadvantage here."

"Bullshit." Frowning, Mike said. "I'm a mere human, and it only took the power of my voice to make you jump and tremble. The only disadvantage you have is your fear to apply your knowledge to break new grounds." He grinned and added, "Grow a backbone... little girl!"

Now I was insulted. I bared my fangs with a hiss and, before I could stop myself, I blurted out "I'll show you backbone..."

Mike chuckled, surprising me. "Finola was right about your potential." More kindly, he said. "All it took was to put a fire under your ego."

"What?!" Taken back, I asked. "I could have drunk you dry!"

Mike shook his head. "Book twenty, chapter four."

After a thought, I gasped. "You are a Legendary...?" Stunned, I asked.

Mike nodded. "I am... if you believe in that nonsense." Calmly, he said. "According to Finola, I am the direct descendant of Galatea, an ivory statue brought to life by the Roman goddess, Venus." he chuckled. "According to her, I could hold my own against any dhampir or werewolf, if I had to, but I have no intention to test that."

"Which is why you are teaching me now." Softly, I said. "Finola seems to be confident that you can handle us."

Mike grunted. "Knowing how to face a vampire, werewolf, or powerful human in the books is a far cry from actually doing it in real time." Serious, he explained. "I have taken on a rogue vampire, and let me tell you... once they grab hold, you are screwed."

"How did you survive?" wincing, I asked.

Mike smiled. "The cleaning crew saved me." Calmly, he replied. "They seemed impressed that I was able to ring the vampire's bells long enough for them to step in."

111122111211211121112132221.content:
Courtney popped her head in, looking no more pale than I, with a curious look on her face as she approached. "Dad is still asleep, and Mom talking to someone named Aoife on the phone." Softly, she said. "Is there anything I can do?"

"You can sit here with your sister for a story." Calmly, Mike said. "After that, will will have a long talk about possible jobs you two can take on in the near future."

Courtney sat down next to me on the carpeted floor, as Mike sat down across from us in the lotus position. He drew in a breath and began... "It was about three years back, then I was just as clueless as the rest of the world about the Masquerade. I was a hardcore private investigator, among the best in the business. Still, the police did not like anyone stepping on their toes, especially not anyone from the private sector. They kept a sharp eye on me, if nothing else to make my job difficult."

"Aren't you all on the same side?" Confused, Courtney asked.

"We are supposed to be." Nodding, Mike replied. "That's another story, though. I got wind of people's dogs and cats going missing in the city park. They were later found bled dry, presumably by some sicko who hated domesticated animals."

"A vampire...?" Curious, Courtney asked.

"Or werewolf..." Wincing, I added.

"If it were a werewolf, you would not have found anything other than some drops of blood and fur." Serious, Mike said. "Only I had not considered that, then. I found grains of charred concrete in the matted fur of the dead animals, and guessed that they had been taken to a old building that had recently burned out."

"Did you find the culprit there?" Softly, I asked. "Who was it?"

Mike frowned. "A little girl, no older than ten." Sadly, he replied. "She was drained and left to die, by a mutual acquaintance of yours, Janelle."

I gasped, then frowned, angry. "Micah..."

Mike nodded. "He will not be causing any further trouble, though." Darkly, he said. "His greedy mistakes have caught the attention of the master."

"Dracula...." Wide eyed, Courtney whispered.

"Micah has been shipped to Transylvania, where he will need to tread far more lightly if he wishes to remain alive." Serious, Mike said. "Monster hunters are in far greater numbers there."

"What happened to the little girl?" Worried, I asked.

Mike sighed. "Her name was Tia Storm. The poor child had no idea what she had become, and was far too innocent to drink from humans." Sadly, he said. "Although it seemed impossible, I knew that I had met my first vampire." He chuckled. "It's ironic, as I lived in a house that once belonged to the Van Helsing clan."

"What did you do with her?" Wincing, I asked.

At this point, both Courtney and I were hanging onto every word, not wanting to miss a single detail of Mike's story as he continued. "I convinced her to come with me, and I took her to my car, only I sensed we were not alone." Serious, he said. "It is nothing a human gains at birth, it is something they develop, after years of being in dangerous situations... I knew we were not alone, and we were being watched."

"Micah." Softly, Courtney said.

"I got Tia into the car and rushed to get in myself." Calmly, Mike said. "The second I shut the car door, someone had landed onto the roof of the car." He frowned. "It was Micah, though I did not know his name then. He looked down into the window with a sadistic smile on his face, baring his fangs."

Courtney took my hand, as if she were frightened, though I knew it was just her excitement from the story. "Did you get out to fight him?" Anxious, she asked.

Mike shook his head. "He wasn't the first perp to jump onto my car." With a grin, he said. "I hit the accelerator and took him for a ride. After hitting a certain speed, I threw the car into a spin and sent him flying into a building."

Courtney winced, only I frowned. "I doubt that slowed him down in the least."

"Any normal human would have been too stunned to even move." Calmly, Mike said. "Only I was dealing with a vampire, something I had never dealt with before. I rolled down the passenger side window as he got up, and let him have it in the shoulder with my .357 special. It knocked him back, but he only smiled more, and I knew conventional weapons were not going to cut it, so I hit the accelerator and hauled ass out of there."

"Aw...!" Disappointed, Courtney wailed. "I thought you fought him!"

"I'm not finished yet." Serious, Mike said. "I took her to my house, which no, you will not be visiting anytime soon. There, I got my less conventional weapons for nonlethal conflicts on other cases. My favorite was a bo staff made of Schinopsis wood."

"Of what...?!" Confused, I asked.

"The hardest wood on Earth." Calmly, Mike replied. "The name comes from Spanish quebrar hacha, which literally means axe breaker." He sighed. "Now, don't scoff, but I had to do a lot of my own doctoring back in the day, so I had some of my own donated blood on hand, in case I needed to give myself a transfusion. I gave her one of the bags to drink."

"You are hardcore...." Stunned, Courtney said. "They need to write a romance novel about your cases."

Mike cleared his throat, hiding a slight blush. "I don't know about that, kid." Gruffly, he said. "Anyway, Micah came calling, and I stepped out to face him with my bo staff. The little punk was fast, but he didn't know shit about fighting. Each time he tried to get past me, I got him with my staff. I even managed to clock him one, throwing him off of his feet..."

"I'm guessing that was when he got ahold of you." Wincing, I said.

Mike nodded. "He got ahold of me, and I couldn't break his grip to save my life." Serious, he said. "I could feel his hot breath on my neck, then he yelled out as if in pain, though I felt nothing. That was when the cleaning crew entered the scene. Seeing them, he released me, and I clocked him with the last of my strength, throwing him clear off me." He chuckled. "I had somehow managed knock the bastard senseless."

Courtney and I applauded, to which Mike shook his head. "I got lucky." Calmly, he said. "I was spent by the time Finola and her team arrived."

"So they took Tia off your hands and made you join." Softly, I said.

Mike nodded. "In a nutshell,... yeah."

"What happened to Tia?" Wincing, Courtney asked.

"Finola adopted her." Simply, Mike replied. "She is here, but she will not come out until she is ready." He smiled. "Now then,... let's talk about putting you two to work."
111122111211211121112132221.title: Mike tells his story.

1111221112112111211121322211.content:
"What job did you have in mind, Mr. Sutherland?" Curious, I asked.

"A cab driver." Calmly, Mike said.

"A what...?" Raising an eyebrow, Courtney asked. She scoffed. "Boring..."

"I did not say you, little miss adventure." Cracking a grin, Mike said. He turned to me. "Cab drivers hear and see things that are not normally observed on the streets."

I nodded. "Cab drivers also go down every street and alley in their district." Calmly, I said. "No one bats an eye at it, either."

"Mr. Ducarla owns a cab company that runs in several cities, called the Knightley Cab Company." Serious, Mike said. "I will get you in touch with the branch officer of this city, a Loretta Hamilton, she will get you started." He raised a finger of warning. "Just don't assume your lineage will give you any perks. She is a strict woman with a business to run... she will fire your ass if you step out of line."

"Which will get me in hot water with the others." Nodding, I said. "I understand."

Mike smiled. "Good girl."

"What about me?" Curious, Courtney asked. "Do I get a paying job too?"

"When you earn it." Serious, Mike replied. "For now, just stay put."

Courtney pouted, but paused as Finola and her associates walked into the office. "My compliments to you, Janelle." Calmly, she said. "Your idea worked. Mr. Victor Van Helsing will be working for us from here on out."

"Do you know who he was looking for at the mall?" Worried, I asked.

Finola nodded. "He was asking around about me." Calmly, she replied. She turned to Mike. "Is she ready for her first job?"

"I'm taking her to the cab company now." Serious, Mike said. "I should have her back before dawn."

Finola nodded then turned back to me. "I expect to hear great things about you in the following weeks, Janelle Lee."

11112211121121112111213222112.content:
"What job can I have?" Curious, Courtney asked.

Finola smiled. "I think we can find the perfect job for you, colleen." Calmly, she said. "How are you at babysitting?"

"Okay, I guess." Shrugging, Courtney said. "Who am I babysitting?"

Finola smiled then called out, "It is safe to come out, Tia."

We all turned to face a tiny, frail-looking girl in a simple white dress, nervously walking out of one of the rooms. She had long silver hair and red eyes. "Who are these people, mommy?" Wincing, she asked.

"This is Janelle Lee, and her sister, Courtney." Patiently, Finola said. "They and their father are dhampirs. Their mother is a psychic vampire."

"Why are they here?" Curious, Tia asked. "Are they in trouble?"

"Janelle Lee is our champion towards peace with the werewolves." Smiling, Finola replied. "Her mother is the long-lost granddaughter of Dracula himself." She then turned to Courtney. "Tia is often left alone for several hours at a time. I am hoping you would be willing to keep her company while we train your sister."

"That doesn't sound too bad." Calmly, Courtney said.

"You are getting me a babysitter?" Surprised, Tia asked. "I'm a big enough girl..."

"A friend to pass the hours until your mom gets back from work." Smiling, Courtney said. "Does that sound better?"

Tia pouted. "I'm not taking orders from you."

Courtney giggled. "I'm not taking them from you, either."

Tia childishly stuck her tongue out, with Courtney doing the same in return. I could only shake my head. "They're going to get along just fine." Bemused, I said.

Finola smiled. "I wonder who will drive who crazy first."

"Us, most likely." giggling, I said.

Finola giggled in return. "The Knightley Cab Company serves humans, vampires and werewolves alike." Calmly, she said. "Loretta Hamilton is aware of the Masquerade, but she is not a thrall. She is what we call a watcher."

"A... watcher?" Confused, I asked.

Finola nodded. "There are select few human bloodlines who are immune to the venom that turns them." Serious, she explained. "The Van Helsing family was among them, and we do our best to keep those few families, as a whole, unaware."

"Those who are..." Wincing, I asked.

"Those individuals who are aware by whatever means, like Loretta Hamilton, we offer jobs within our network." Calmly, Finola replied. "A guaranteed steady paycheck with good perks and protection is enough of an incentive for most to remain silent. We call them watchers because of the actions of Van Helsings.... always watching."

I nodded. "Mike told me that Loretta Hamilton will fire me if I step out of line."

"Indeed she will." Serious, Finola said. "She is a very down to Earth woman, and will not tolerate anyone who does not take their job seriously."

"I can only do my best." shrugging, I said.

"Then that will have to do, colleen." Smiling, Finola said.

111122111211211121112132221121.content:
Mike escorted me while I drove to the Knightley Cab company depot the very next evening, and took me directly to Loretta "Ham" Hamilton. She was a tall and well-built woman, with long auburn hair and green eyes. Professionally dressed, she looked up from her desk to see Mike enter with me into her office. "You know who I am and why I am here." Flatly Mike said. "I'll leave her in your capable hands."

With that, he left, and Loretta sighed. "I got a call from the owner and CEO of this company, Mr. Ducarla, last night, to give you a chance as a cab driver." in a forced calm, she said. "Only, I run a tight ship here, so I need to know... why does a well-off girl like you want to be a cab driver?"

"I can only work nights due to an extreme photosensitivity, which limits my options." Honestly, I replied. "I asked someone who is helping me deal with this if she knew of any jobs I can take, and she arranged this meeting."

"I see..." Her face softening, Loretta said. "Well, take this into consideration before we move forward, Miss Lee." She took a breath. "Knightley Cab Company keeps its vehicles in good working order, and needs good drivers to stave off the threat of Uber, Lyft, and similar companies."

"I think I understand." Courtly, I said.

"Do you, now?" Unimpressed, Loretta asked.

"It's my responsibility to make certain the cab I am assigned is returned both clean and in working order, with my quota of fares filled every night." Calmly, I said. "Any damages or cleaning costs come out of my paycheck, and too many of either, or too low of quotas, will result in my termination..." I sighed. "Mr Sutherland gave me the rundown of the rules and regulations."

Loretta raised a single eyebrow. "I just don't know." Reluctant, she said. After a thought, she added, "I consider myself a good boss and an even better friend once you earn that friendship, but cross me and you will wish you were never born."

I gave a sigh of relief, which surprised Loretta, judging by her expression. "You sound just like my mom..."

Loretta gave the hint of a smile. "I'll give you a chance, but not because Mr Ducarla says so... but because you did not use your lineage to gain favors."

I nodded. "I will do my best to prove myself a good employee, ma'am."

Loretta smiled. "Just call me Ham." Calmly, she said. "We will see if you succeed or fail... be here just after dusk, I do not tolerate tardiness."

"Thank you for giving me a chance... Ham." Grateful, I said. "I really appreciate it."

"Just get out of here, and be back on time tomorrow night." Gruffly, Loretta said.

I nodded and left, happy to have a job.

1111221112112111211121322211211.content:
I arrived at the depot one minute after dusk. I had learned that, if I covered up properly, I could be in the light of the setting sun without much risk of harm or notice. In this strange world, no one bats an eye at a teenager's unique fashion sense. Loretta smiled upon seeing me enter. "I wasn't expecting you just yet." Calmly, she said. "I'm impressed."

"I was serious when I said I needed a job." Softly, I said. "High expectations at home..."

"I can imagine." Nodding, Loretta replied. She motioned to a cab near them. "You will drive cab 7B. Other cabbies have called her 'odd ball,' and swear she is cursed or haunted, but it's not the cab, it's the district she is assigned to."

"The neutral grounds." Whispering, I said.

Loretta nodded. "I am giving you this district because one, no one else wants it, and two, I want to see if you can handle the worst this job has to offer before moving you up into easier areas to drive."

"The newbie test." Softly, I said.

"I'm glad you see it as that." Honestly, Loretta said. "Most new cabbies see it as a way to weed out the weak and keep only the hardcore."

"Mr Sutherland told me that being a cabbie is not for the faint of heart." Calmly, I replied. "I believe him."

Loretta nodded. "I have some paperwork for you to fill out, and then I will take you out on your orientation." Serious, she said. "We'll see if you can cut it."

About an hour later, Loretta and I were on the road, driving between churches and cemeteries to old mansions and dense forests. "This is the most isolated and, oftentimes, most dangerous part of the city." Softly, Loretta explained. "People are slow to trust strangers here, so new cab drivers are eyed suspiciously."

"Much like the small towns of the Midwest." Calmly, I said. "Everyone knows everyone, so, when a stranger comes, everyone is on guard."

A call came in from dispatch... "We have a pick up at the Manifold office building, two young teenagers dropped off at the wrong place by Uber."

"Roger that." Calmly, Loretta radioed back. "En route." She turned to me. "Do you know the way?"

I nodded. "Yes, Ham. I used to deliver newspapers in this neighborhood."

Loretta cracked a grin. "So they do know you here." Softly, she said. "Interesting..."

Within minutes, we arrived at the Manifold office complex, where I was surprised to find Courtney and Matt waiting, with Aoife carrying a bemused look on her face. "That's my little sister and my friend's little brother." Worried, I said. "What are they doing out here alone at this time?"

Loretta sighed. "Go find out."

Upon stopping the car, Aoife motioned for me to remain in the cab. "There is nothing to be concerned about, colleen." Calmly, she said. "Two former thralls on either side had decided to take it upon themselves to have these two meet." Her face turned dark. "You know the penalty..."

I nodded but remained silent. Only Loretta asked, "Any diplomatic damages?"

Aoife giggled. "Other than a rather jealous young female werewolf, no." Calmly, she said. "This young cub is quite the charmer..."

Both Matt and Courtney blushed at that, causing me to sigh. "We will talk about this after work, sis." Softly, I said. "Please get in."

Matt opened the door for Courtney, causing me to frown slightly, which Loretta noticed. "Patience, girl." Whispering, she said. "Remember your other job..."

I sighed and silently nodded as Aoife came to my window. "The former thralls had intended to sour your relationship by having their meet and greet go south." Softly, she explained. "Only these two are far too young and innocent for that nonsense. They just talked, and are now fast friends."

That only caused me to sigh. "Which means they are now diplomats, too."

Aoife grinned. "Precisely." She again giggled. "That is, if Matt's first crush allows it."

I could only shake my head.
